Eggnog Pancakes

Jump to Recipe

Start your holiday brunch off right with these delightful Eggnog Pancakes! Combining the rich, creamy flavors of traditional eggnog with fluffy pancake goodness, this recipe is sure to bring joy to your breakfast table. Perfect for cozy winter mornings or festive gatherings, these pancakes not only taste amazing but also fill your kitchen with the warm, inviting aroma of nutmeg and vanilla. With simple ingredients like all-purpose flour, baking powder, and a splash of eggnog, you can whip up a batch of these festive treats in no time. Whether you’re enjoying them with maple syrup, whipped cream, or fresh fruit, Eggnog Pancakes are the perfect way to celebrate the season and create cherished memories with family and friends. Get ready to indulge in a breakfast that’s as special as the holidays themselves!

Ingredients

all-purpose flour

For a gluten-free option, substitute with a gluten-free all-purpose flour blend. If you want a nuttier flavor, consider using whole wheat flour or spelt flour, but keep in mind that it may alter the texture slightly.

baking powder

Ensure your baking powder is fresh for the best rise. If you run out, you can substitute with 1/2 teaspoon baking soda and 1 teaspoon vinegar or lemon juice.

sugar

You can replace granulated sugar with brown sugar for a deeper flavor. For a healthier option, consider using coconut sugar or a sugar substitute like stevia, though you may need to adjust the quantity.

nutmeg

Freshly grated nutmeg will provide a more vibrant flavor than pre-ground. If you don't have nutmeg, you can substitute with ground cinnamon or allspice.

eggnog

If you prefer a non-dairy option, use almond milk or coconut milk mixed with a bit of vanilla and nutmeg to mimic eggnog flavor. You can also make homemade eggnog for a fresher taste.

egg

For a vegan alternative, use a flax egg (1 tablespoon ground flaxseed mixed with 3 tablespoons water) or unsweetened applesauce (1/4 cup) as a binding agent.

butter

Melted coconut oil or vegetable oil can be used as a substitute for butter, which will also make the pancakes dairy-free. If using oil, use slightly less than the amount of butter.

vanilla extract

Using pure vanilla extract will enhance the flavor more than imitation vanilla. For a twist, consider adding a teaspoon of almond extract for a different flavor profile.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Mix Dry Ingredients

    In a large mixing bowl, combine 1 cup of all-purpose flour, 2 teaspoons of baking powder, 2 tablespoons of sugar, and 1/2 teaspoon of nutmeg. Whisk them together until evenly mixed. This step is crucial as it ensures that the baking powder is evenly distributed, which helps your pancakes rise nicely.

  • Step 2: Prepare Wet Ingredients

    In a separate bowl, whisk together 1 cup of eggnog, 1 large egg, 2 tablespoons of melted butter, and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. Make sure the melted butter is not too hot to prevent cooking the egg. This mixture will add moisture and flavor to your pancakes.

  • Step 3: Combine Ingredients

    Pour the wet ingredients into the bowl with the dry ingredients. Gently stir until just combined. Remember, it's okay to have some lumps in the batter. Overmixing can lead to tough pancakes, so mix just until you don't see any dry flour.

  • Step 4: Heat the Skillet

    Preheat a non-stick skillet or griddle over medium heat. Lightly grease the surface with butter or cooking spray. This step is important to prevent sticking and to ensure an even cooking surface. You can test if the skillet is ready by sprinkling a few drops of water on it; if they sizzle and evaporate, it's ready.

  • Step 5: Cook the Pancakes

    Pour 1/4 cup of batter onto the skillet for each pancake. Cook until bubbles form on the surface (about 2-3 minutes). When the edges look set and the bubbles pop without leaving a wet surface, it's time to flip. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes on the other side until golden brown.

  • Step 6: Serve and Enjoy

    Once cooked, transfer the pancakes to a plate and keep them warm in an oven set to low heat while you finish cooking the rest. Serve warm with maple syrup, whipped cream, or a sprinkle of additional nutmeg for an extra festive touch.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the best way to measure flour accurately?

To measure flour accurately, use a spoon to fluff it up in the container, then spoon it into your measuring cup without packing it down. Level it off with a straight edge, like a knife, for an exact measurement.

How can I substitute if I don't have baking powder?

If you don't have baking powder, you can make a substitute by mixing 1/4 teaspoon baking soda with 1/2 teaspoon vinegar or lemon juice for each teaspoon of baking powder needed.

What type of eggnog should I use?

You can use store-bought or homemade eggnog. Just make sure it’s well-chilled, as this helps incorporate it smoothly into your batter.

Is it okay if my pancake batter is lumpy?

Yes! It's completely normal for pancake batter to be lumpy. Overmixing can lead to tough pancakes, so mix until just combined.

How do I know when to flip the pancakes?

Flip the pancakes when you see bubbles forming on the surface and the edges look set. This usually takes about 2-3 minutes. If they are browning too quickly, lower the heat.

What can I do to prevent my pancakes from sticking to the skillet?

To prevent sticking, make sure your skillet is preheated and use a little melted butter or oil to lightly grease the surface before pouring in the batter.

Can I make these pancakes ahead of time?

Yes! You can cook the pancakes ahead of time and keep them warm in a low oven (about 200°F) while you finish cooking the rest. They can also be stored in the fridge for a few days or frozen for longer storage.

What toppings go well with eggnog pancakes?

Eggnog pancakes pair wonderfully with maple syrup, whipped cream, or a sprinkle of additional nutmeg or cinnamon for extra flavor.

How do I store leftover pancakes?

Store leftover pancakes in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days or freeze them separated by parchment paper in a freezer-safe bag for up to 3 months.

What should I do if my pancakes are burned on the outside but raw inside?

If this happens, reduce your skillet's heat and allow the pancakes to cook more slowly. Make sure to flip them only when they're ready to avoid burning.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For a gluten-free option, substitute the all-purpose flour with a 1-to-1 gluten-free baking flour blend. To make dairy-free pancakes, use almond milk or coconut milk eggnog and a plant-based butter substitute. Additionally, for a lower sugar option, use a sugar alternative like stevia or monk fruit sweetener.

Pairings

Pair these Eggnog Pancakes with crispy bacon or sausage links for a savory contrast. For beverages, consider serving with freshly brewed coffee, spiced chai tea, or a festive holiday mimosa made with champagne and orange juice.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the pancakes stacked on a warm plate, drizzled with maple syrup or a spiced eggnog syrup for extra flavor. Garnish with a sprinkle of nutmeg or powdered sugar, and add a dollop of whipped cream on top. For a festive touch, add some candied cranberries or pomegranate seeds for color and tartness.

Eggnog Pancakes

25 min
$5
200 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

EggsDairyGluten

Dietary Tags:

Vegetarian

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Breakfast

Tags:

BreakfastFestiveEasy

Description

Fluffy pancakes infused with the rich flavors of eggnog, perfect for a festive breakfast!

Ingredients

  • all-purpose flour: 1 cup
  • baking powder: 2 teaspoons
  • sugar: 2 tablespoons
  • nutmeg: 1/2 teaspoon
  • eggnog: 1 cup
  • egg: 1 large
  • butter: 2 tablespoons, melted
  • vanilla extract: 1 teaspoon

Date Created:

11/21/2024
